information: The reception for cross-genre artists at country music award shows has been mixed historically. Favorable precedents include Beyoncé winning a CMA Award for a collaboration with The Chicks, and Justin Timberlake winning a CMA with Chris Stapleton. Lil Nas X also won CMA Awards for "Old Town Road." However, many artists crossing over face resistance from traditional voters, and the Album of the Year award typically goes to established country artists. Post Malone himself has a history of receiving numerous Grammy nominations without winning; at the 2025 Grammy Awards, he was nominated for eight awards and lost all of them, bringing his career total to 18 nominations without a win.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: Slightly more likely that he wins at least one award (Yes)
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: ACM voters coalesce around more traditional country choices: Zach Bryan/Lainey Wilson/Luke Combs sweep the marquee track categories; Music Event goes to a different duet; Visual Media favors a more artistically distinctive video. Because Malone’s four nods are mostly tied to the same material, a single-voter-sentiment headwind shuts him out across all four.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: “I Had Some Help” with Morgan Wallen converts one of its big nominations—most plausibly Single of the Year or Music Event—on sheer commercial dominance and broad industry embrace, or the video wins Visual Media. One win is enough for a Yes resolution.
forecast.rationale:
Post Malone has four ACM nominations, likely concentrated around his blockbuster duet “I Had Some Help,” which dominated charts and radio in 2024. The ACMs have historically been willing to reward massive, radio-driven hits and high-profile collaborations, and Nashville has been comparatively welcoming to crossover moments. That profile makes at least one win the status-quo expectation.

Countervailing factors: cross-genre entrants can face resistance from traditional voters; lyric-focused categories like Song of the Year can tilt toward critical darlings (e.g., Zach Bryan). Also, Malone’s awards-track record (0-for-18 at the Grammys as of 2025) hints at some voter reluctance in major academies. Importantly, his nominations are correlated—if voters are cool on “I Had Some Help,” he could miss across all four.

Why not higher: Voter pushback against crossover/collabs, strong competition from core-country favorites, and category correlation elevate shutout risk.
Why not lower: Four bites at the apple materially increase his at-least-one-win chances; “I Had Some Help” was arguably the year’s defining commercial single in country, and ACMs often reflect that.

What would move me up: Credible industry chatter suggesting broad ACM support for the track; pre-show awards (if any) breaking toward the song; signs that voters are rewarding its commercial impact. What would move me down: Reports of a sentiment shift against crossover wins, a leaked winners list/credible rumor set favoring Zach Bryan/Lainey Wilson/Luke Combs in the overlapping categories, or any late controversy affecting Malone or the duet.
